question.title: Will Ukraine join NATO before 2030?
question.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, Ukraine is officially granted membership in NATO, as confirmed by a formal announcement from NATO's Secretary General or the NATO Summit. The membership must be ratified by all current NATO member states, and Ukraine must fulfill all necessary criteria for membership as outlined in NATO's membership action plan. Any interim agreements or partnerships will not count as membership. In the event of a membership application being approved but not yet ratified by all member states, the question will resolve as No.

question.title: Conditional on Ukraine joining NATO before 2030, will Ukraine achieve full operational interoperability with NATO forces by 2027?
question.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2027, Ukraine has achieved full operational interoperability with NATO forces as defined by the NATO standards for interoperability, which includes successful joint exercises, integration of command and control systems, and the ability to operate seamlessly with NATO forces in a combined mission. This must be confirmed by official NATO reports or statements from NATO leadership. Additionally, the interoperability must be demonstrated in at least one multinational operation involving NATO member states. The resolution will also consider any credible assessments from defense analysts or reputable defense publications (e.g., Defense News, Jane's Defence) regarding Ukraine's interoperability status with NATO.

Any interim agreements or partnerships will not count as membership. In the event of a membership application being approved but not yet ratified by all member states, the question will resolve as No.

question.title: Will NATO conduct joint military exercises with Ukraine before 2028?
question.body: This question will resolve as Yes if NATO conducts joint military exercises with Ukraine before January 1, 2028. The exercises must be officially announced and involve active participation of NATO member states alongside Ukrainian armed forces, with a minimum duration of 3 days. The exercises must be reported by at least two reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, New York Times, Washington Post) to ensure credibility. Any informal or unofficial training sessions do not count towards this resolution.

question.title: Will a new infectious disease prompt the development of nuclear biocontainment technologies before 2030?
question.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a new infectious disease emerges that leads to the development and deployment of nuclear biocontainment technologies. A 'new infectious disease' is defined as a pathogen that has not previously been identified in humans and is capable of human-to-human transmission, leading to an outbreak. The development of nuclear biocontainment technologies must be officially recognized and reported by a reputable source such as the World Health Organization (WHO), the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), or a major news organization (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times). The technologies must be operational and intended for use against the new infectious disease, and not merely proposed or in the planning stages. If the technologies are developed for multiple diseases, the question will still resolve as Yes if the new infectious disease is included in the scope of the technologies.

question.title: Conditional on a new infectious disease prompting the development of nuclear biocontainment technologies before 2030, will governments increase funding for pandemic preparedness measures due to a new infectious disease by 2027?
question.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2027, any government (federal, state, or local) in a recognized country increases its budgetary allocation for pandemic preparedness measures in response to the emergence of a new infectious disease. The increase must be publicly documented and reported by reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, New York Times, Washington Post) or through official government announcements. The new infectious disease must be classified as a significant threat by the World Health Organization (WHO) or equivalent health authority, leading to a measurable increase in funding compared to the year prior. Temporary or one-time funding increases for specific events or emergencies that do not lead to sustained funding changes will not count towards this resolution.

Criterion for condition: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a new infectious disease emerges that leads to the development and deployment of nuclear biocontainment technologies. If the condition is not met, resolves N/A.

question.title: Conditional on a new infectious disease prompting the development of nuclear biocontainment technologies before 2030, will it also result in the creation of a global health surveillance system by 2035?
question.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2035, a global health surveillance system is officially established in response to the new infectious disease that prompted the development of nuclear biocontainment technologies. The surveillance system must meet the following criteria:

- The system must be designed to monitor, report, and respond to infectious disease outbreaks on a global scale, with participation from multiple countries and international health organizations such as the World Health Organization (WHO).
- The surveillance system must include real-time data collection, analysis, and sharing mechanisms that allow for rapid identification and response to infectious disease threats.
- The creation of this system must be documented by official reports, declarations, or agreements from recognized global health authorities, such as the WHO, and must be operational, not merely proposed or in a planning stage.
- In the event of a partial implementation, the question will resolve as Yes if the system is intended for global application and not limited to specific regions or countries. Temporary or ad-hoc systems for specific outbreaks do not count towards this resolution.

Criterion for condition: A new infectious disease must emerge and lead to the development and deployment of nuclear biocontainment technologies by December 31, 2030. The new disease must be a previously unidentified pathogen capable of human-to-human transmission, causing an outbreak. The nuclear biocontainment technologies must be officially recognized and reported by reputable sources like the WHO, CDC, or major news organizations, and must be operational and intended for use against the new disease.

question.title: Will a new infectious disease lead to the establishment of international biocontainment protocols by 2028?
question.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2028, an infectious disease emerges that leads to the establishment of internationally recognized biocontainment protocols. The following conditions must be met for the protocols to be considered established: 1. The protocols must be formally adopted by at least three major international health organizations, such as the World Health Organization (WHO), the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), or the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC). 2. The protocols must be implemented in response to the disease, addressing containment measures, travel restrictions, and public health guidelines. 3. The disease must be classified as a significant threat to global health, as determined by the aforementioned organizations. 4. The establishment of protocols must be publicly announced and documented in reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). If multiple diseases emerge, the resolution will be based on the first disease that meets these criteria.

Criteria for the outcome (Q):

2. The development of nuclear biocontainment technologies must be officially recognized and reported by a reputable source such as the World Health Organization (WHO), the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), or a major news organization (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times).
3. The technologies must be operational and intended for use against the new infectious disease, and not merely proposed or in the planning stages.
4. If the technologies are developed for multiple diseases, the question will still resolve as Yes if the new infectious disease is included in the scope of the technologies.

If the condition is not met, the question resolves as N/A.

question.title: Given the development of nuclear biocontainment technologies due to a new infectious disease, will significant advancements in vaccine technology occur by 2030?
question.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, any of the following significant advancements in vaccine technology are recognized and documented as a direct result of a new infectious disease outbreak:

1. Development of a new vaccine platform that demonstrates efficacy in clinical trials against the outbreak disease.
2. Significant improvements in vaccine production methods that reduce time to market for a vaccine in response to the outbreak, as recognized by regulatory agencies such as the FDA or EMA.
3. Successful implementation of a novel delivery method for vaccines that is adopted in response to the outbreak and shows improved efficacy or accessibility.

Advancements must be reported by reputable sources, including peer-reviewed journals or major news outlets (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post), and must be acknowledged by public health organizations such as the WHO or CDC. The advancements must not be incremental improvements but rather substantial innovations directly linked to the outbreak.

question.title: Will a Formula 1 Grand Prix be hosted in a country currently under international sanctions by 2030?
question.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a Formula 1 Grand Prix is officially scheduled and hosted in a country that is currently under international sanctions as defined by the United Nations or the European Union. The sanctions must be in effect at the time of the event, and the hosting must be confirmed by Formula 1 Management through an official announcement or documentation. If the country is removed from the sanctions list before the event, the question will resolve as No. Temporary events or exhibitions do not count towards this resolution.

question.title: Given a Formula 1 Grand Prix is hosted in a country currently under international sanctions by 2025, will it also be held in a country with a controversial human rights record by 2025?
question.body:
This question explores the intersection of international sanctions and human rights records in the context of hosting a Formula 1 Grand Prix.

**Condition (P):**
Will a Formula 1 Grand Prix be hosted in a country currently under international sanctions by 2025?
- This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a Formula 1 Grand Prix is officially scheduled and held in a country that is currently under international sanctions recognized by at least one major international body (such as the United Nations or the European Union). The sanctions must be in effect at the time of the event, and the event must be confirmed by the official Formula 1 calendar or an official announcement from the Formula 1 organization. Temporary events or exhibitions do not count, and the Grand Prix must be part of the regular Formula 1 season. If the country is removed from sanctions before the event, the resolution will be No.

**Outcome (Q):**
Will a Formula 1 Grand Prix be held in a country with a controversial human rights record by 2025?
- This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a Formula 1 Grand Prix is officially scheduled or held in a country recognized by credible human rights organizations (such as Amnesty International or Human Rights Watch) as having a controversial human rights record. A controversial human rights record is defined as a country that has been reported to have significant issues such as political repression, lack of freedom of speech, arbitrary detentions, or discrimination against marginalized groups. The confirmation must come from an official Formula 1 announcement or credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post). If the race is held in a country that is later determined to have a controversial human rights record based on reports released after the event, the question will resolve as No.

**Combined Question:**
Given a Formula 1 Grand Prix is hosted in a country currently under international sanctions by 2025, will it also be held in a country with a controversial human rights record by 2025?
